content_cloud_description: Clouds form when air rises from the Earth’s surface. As this air rises, it cools, water vapor condenses on tiny particles in the atmosphere, and forms clouds. Check out the touchscreen under the windows to learn more about clouds, and look outside to identify the clouds you can see in the sky.

content_severe_weather_description: Severe weather includes tornadoes, thunderstorms, flooding, snowstorms, hurricanes, and severe winds. These dramatic events can impact human health and the economy. Since 1980, the U.S. has had over 200 weather or climate related weather events that each caused damages reaching or exceeding one billion dollars.
content_study_weather_description: Anemometers are instruments that measure the speed of wind. Some anemometers also include a weather vane which shows which direction the wind is blowing. The highest wind speed ever recorded here at the NCAR Mesa Lab was a 147 mph gust on January 23, 1971.
content_microburst_description: Microbursts are strong, vertical winds that suddenly form underneath thunderstorms. These downdrafts can have speeds over 100 mph. Microbursts are very dangerous for airplanes during takeoff or landing. To address this safety issue, in the 1980s NCAR scientists developed a microburst detection system that makes air travel much safer.
content_past_climate_description: How can we learn what Earth’s climate was like in ancient times before humans began writing about it? Some natural features provide clues about climates of the past. Tree rings of different widths tell us about growing conditions from year to year. Was it dry or wet? Cool or hot?
content_greenhouse_gases_description: Charles David Keeling began measuring carbon dioxide (CO2) levels on Hawaii’s Mauna Loa Observatory in 1958. These measurements make up the Keeling Curve, which shows that CO2 values have increased from 330 to over 400 parts per million (ppm). Greenhouse gases such as CO2 trap heat in the atmosphere and warm the Earth’s temperature.
visitor_intro: The NCAR Visitor Center is located at the NCAR Mesa Lab in Boulder, Colorado. Admission is always free.
visitor_hours_content:
Weekdays: 8:00 am - 5:00 pm
Weekends: 9:00 am - 4:00 pm
Holidays: 9:00 am - 4:00 pm

The visitor center is open every day except for two annual shut down days in the spring and fall. View our visitor website for updates when these shut downs are scheduled.
visitor_cafeteria_content:
Breakfast, 8:00 am - 9:30 am
Lunch, 11:30 - 1:30 pm

The cafeteria is open weekdays only, except holidays. The cafeteria accepts only cash.
visitor_accessibility_content: Addition information about our accessibility accomodations can be found on our website.
visitor_accessiblity_parking_intro: NCAR's Mesa Lab Visitor Center offers two entrances for those with mobility impairments and their companions.
visitor_accessibility_parking_content1: This is a secure driveway and entrance, therefore one must call NCAR (303.497.1139) in advance to gain access to the two accessible parking spaces or to drop visitors off at the main entrance.
visitor_accessibility_parking_content2: The second option is to park in the accessible parking area at the back (south side) of the building directly next to our delivery dock. Please buzz the intercom located next to the inside door and our security staff will facilitate your entrance. (Please feel free to ask via the intercom for a staff escort to meet you at this entrance if desired.) All doors in this area are automatic. Once inside, follow the green dots to the elevator. Enter the elevator, press "G" for Ground Level, and it will transport you to the first floor of our Visitor Center.
visitor_accessibility_elevators_intro: All exhibits and public areas are accessible by elevator.
visitor_accessibility_restrooms_intro: A wheelchair accessible restroom is available on the second floor in the Climate Future exhibit area.
